1713.text:
head and doubtfully smiled, as the carriage
rolled away.

1720.text:
That night—it was the fourteenth of August—he
sat up late, and wrote two fervent letters;

1726.text:
one was to Lucie, explaining the strong obligation
he was under to go to Paris, and showing her,

1733.text:
at length, the reasons that he had, for feeling
confident that he could become involved in

1738.text:
no personal danger there; the other was to
the Doctor, confiding Lucie and their dear

1744.text:
child to his care, and dwelling on the same
topics with the strongest assurances. To both,

1751.text:
he wrote that he would despatch letters in
proof of his safety, immediately after his

1756.text:
arrival.
It was a hard day, that day of being among

1760.text:
them, with the first reservation of their
joint lives on his mind. It was a hard matter

1766.text:
to preserve the innocent deceit of which they
were profoundly unsuspicious. But, an affectionate

1774.text:
glance at his wife, so happy and busy, made
him resolute not to tell her what impended

1780.text:
(he had been half moved to do it, so strange
it was to him to act in anything without her

1786.text:
quiet aid), and the day passed quickly. Early
in the evening he embraced her, and her scarcely

1794.text:
less dear namesake, pretending that he would
return by-and-bye (an imaginary engagement

1800.text:
took him out, and he had secreted a valise
of clothes ready), and so he emerged into

1805.text:
the heavy mist of the heavy streets, with
a heavier heart.

1814.text:
The unseen force was drawing him fast to itself,
now, and all the tides and winds were setting

1821.text:
straight and strong towards it. He left his
two letters with a trusty porter, to be delivered

1828.text:
half an hour before midnight, and no sooner;
took horse for Dover; and began his journey.

1835.text:
"For the love of Heaven, of justice, of generosity,
of the honour of your noble name!" was the

1842.text:
poor prisoner's cry with which he strengthened
his sinking heart, as he left all that was

1848.text:
dear on earth behind him, and floated away
for the Loadstone Rock.

1857.text:
The end of the second book.

1866.text: Book the Third—the Track of a Storm

1870.text:
Chapter I. In Secret
The traveller fared slowly on his way, who

1876.text:
fared towards Paris from England in the autumn
of the year one thousand seven hundred and

1882.text:
ninety-two. More than enough of bad roads,
bad equipages, and bad horses, he would have

1888.text:
encountered to delay him, though the fallen
and unfortunate King of France had been upon

1894.text:
his throne in all his glory; but, the changed
times were fraught with other obstacles than

1901.text:
these. Every town-gate and village taxing-house
had its band of citizen-patriots, with their

1907.text:
national muskets in a most explosive state
of readiness, who stopped all comers and goers,

1915.text:
cross-questioned them, inspected their papers,
looked for their names in lists of their own,

1921.text:
turned them back, or sent them on, or stopped
them and laid them in hold, as their capricious

1927.text:
judgment or fancy deemed best for the dawning
Republic One and Indivisible, of Liberty,

1934.text:
Equality, Fraternity, or Death.
A very few French leagues of his journey were

1941.text:
accomplished, when Charles Darnay began to
perceive that for him along these country

1947.text:
roads there was no hope of return until he
should have been declared a good citizen at

1953.text:
Paris. Whatever might befall now, he must
on to his journey's end. Not a mean village

1961.text:
closed upon him, not a common barrier dropped
across the road behind him, but he knew it

1967.text:
to be another iron door in the series that
was barred between him and England. The universal

1974.text:
watchfulness so encompassed him, that if he
had been taken in a net, or were being forwarded

1980.text:
to his destination in a cage, he could not
have felt his freedom more completely gone.

1988.text:
This universal watchfulness not only stopped
him on the highway twenty times in a stage,

1994.text:
but retarded his progress twenty times in
a day, by riding after him and taking him

2000.text:
back, riding before him and stopping him by
anticipation, riding with him and keeping

2006.text:
him in charge. He had been days upon his journey
in France alone, when he went to bed tired

2012.text:
out, in a little town on the high road, still
a long way from Paris.

2019.text:
Nothing but the production of the afflicted
Gabelle's letter from his prison of the Abbaye

2024.text:
would have got him on so far. His difficulty
at the guard-house in this small place had

2030.text:
been such, that he felt his journey to have
come to a crisis. And he was, therefore, as

2036.text:
little surprised as a man could be, to find
himself awakened at the small inn to which

2041.text:
he had been remitted until morning, in the
middle of the night.

2045.text:
Awakened by a timid local functionary and
three armed patriots in rough red caps and

2053.text:
with pipes in their mouths, who sat down on
the bed.

2057.text:
"Emigrant," said the functionary, "I am going
to send you on to Paris, under an escort."

2063.text:
"Citizen, I desire nothing more than to get
to Paris, though I could dispense with the

2069.text:
escort."
"Silence!" growled a red-cap, striking at

2073.text:
the coverlet with the butt-end of his musket.
"Peace, aristocrat!"

2078.text:
"It is as the good patriot says," observed
the timid functionary. "You are an aristocrat,

2085.text:
and must have an escort—and must pay for
it."

2088.text:
"I have no choice," said Charles Darnay.
"Choice! Listen to him!" cried the same scowling

2096.text:
red-cap. "As if it was not a favour to be
protected from the lamp-iron!"

2101.text:
"It is always as the good patriot says," observed
the functionary. "Rise and dress yourself,

2109.text:
emigrant."
Darnay complied, and was taken back to the

2113.text:
guard-house, where other patriots in rough
red caps were smoking, drinking, and sleeping,

2120.text:
by a watch-fire. Here he paid a heavy price
for his escort, and hence he started with

2126.text:
it on the wet, wet roads at three o'clock
in the morning.

2131.text:
The escort were two mounted patriots in red
caps and tri-coloured cockades, armed with

2138.text:
national muskets and sabres, who rode one
on either side of him.

2143.text:
The escorted governed his own horse, but a
loose line was attached to his bridle, the

2149.text:
end of which one of the patriots kept girded
round his wrist. In this state they set forth

2155.text:
with the sharp rain driving in their faces:
clattering at a heavy dragoon trot over the

2161.text:
uneven town pavement, and out upon the mire-deep
roads. In this state they traversed without

2169.text:
change, except of horses and pace, all the
mire-deep leagues that lay between them and

2176.text:
the capital.
They travelled in the night, halting an hour

2181.text:
or two after daybreak, and lying by until
the twilight fell. The escort were so wretchedly

2188.text:
clothed, that they twisted straw round their
bare legs, and thatched their ragged shoulders

2195.text:
to keep the wet off. Apart from the personal
discomfort of being so attended, and apart

2201.text:
from such considerations of present danger
as arose from one of the patriots being chronically

2207.text:
drunk, and carrying his musket very recklessly,
Charles Darnay did not allow the restraint

2214.text:
that was laid upon him to awaken any serious
fears in his breast; for, he reasoned with

2220.text:
himself that it could have no reference to
the merits of an individual case that was

2225.text:
not yet stated, and of representations, confirmable
by the prisoner in the Abbaye, that were not

2232.text:
yet made.
But when they came to the town of Beauvais—which

2238.text:
they did at eventide, when the streets were
filled with people—he could not conceal

2243.text:
from himself that the aspect of affairs was
very alarming. An ominous crowd gathered to

2250.text:
see him dismount of the posting-yard, and
many voices called out loudly, "Down with

2256.text:
the emigrant!"
He stopped in the act of swinging himself

2260.text:
out of his saddle, and, resuming it as his
safest place, said:

2265.text:
"Emigrant, my friends! Do you not see me here,
in France, of my own will?"

2271.text:
"You are a cursed emigrant," cried a farrier,
making at him in a furious manner through

2278.text:
the press, hammer in hand; "and you are a
cursed aristocrat!"

2284.text:
The postmaster interposed himself between
this man and the rider's bridle (at which

2290.text:
he was evidently making), and soothingly said,
"Let him be; let him be! He will be judged

2295.text:
at Paris."
"Judged!" repeated the farrier, swinging his

2300.text:
hammer. "Ay! and condemned as a traitor."
At this the crowd roared approval.

2308.text:
Checking the postmaster, who was for turning
his horse's head to the yard (the drunken

2314.text:
patriot sat composedly in his saddle looking
on, with the line round his wrist), Darnay

2320.text:
said, as soon as he could make his voice heard:
"Friends, you deceive yourselves, or you are

2326.text:
deceived. I am not a traitor."
"He lies!" cried the smith. "He is a traitor

2334.text:
since the decree. His life is forfeit to the
people. His cursed life is not his own!"

2343.text:
At the instant when Darnay saw a rush in the
eyes of the crowd, which another instant would

2349.text:
have brought upon him, the postmaster turned
his horse into the yard, the escort rode in

2355.text:
close upon his horse's flanks, and the postmaster
shut and barred the crazy double gates. The

2362.text:
farrier struck a blow upon them with his hammer,
and the crowd groaned; but, no more was done.

2370.text:
"What is this decree that the smith spoke
of?" Darnay asked the postmaster, when he

2376.text:
had thanked him, and stood beside him in the
yard.

2380.text:
"Truly, a decree for selling the property
of emigrants."

2388.text:
"The day I left England!"
"Everybody says it is but one of several,

2394.text:
and that there will be others—if there are
not already—banishing all emigrants, and

2399.text:
condemning all to death who return. That is
what he meant when he said your life was not

2404.text:
your own."
"But there are no such decrees yet?"

2408.text:
"What do I know!" said the postmaster, shrugging
his shoulders; "there may be, or there will

2414.text:
be. It is all the same. What would you have?"
They rested on some straw in a loft until

2422.text:
the middle of the night, and then rode forward
again when all the town was asleep. Among

2428.text:
the many wild changes observable on familiar
things which made this wild ride unreal, not

2435.text:
the least was the seeming rarity of sleep.
After long and lonely spurring over dreary

2442.text:
roads, they would come to a cluster of poor
cottages, not steeped in darkness, but all

2448.text:
glittering with lights, and would find the
people, in a ghostly manner in the dead of

2453.text:
the night, circling hand in hand round a shrivelled
tree of Liberty, or all drawn up together

2460.text:
singing a Liberty song. Happily, however,
there was sleep in Beauvais that night to

2467.text:
help them out of it and they passed on once
more into solitude and loneliness: jingling

2473.text:
through the untimely cold and wet, among impoverished
fields that had yielded no fruits of the earth

2480.text:
that year, diversified by the blackened remains
of burnt houses, and by the sudden emergence

2487.text:
from ambuscade, and sharp reining up across
their way, of patriot patrols on the watch

2494.text:
on all the roads.
Daylight at last found them before the wall

2499.text:
of Paris. The barrier was closed and strongly
guarded when they rode up to it.

2505.text:
"Where are the papers of this prisoner?" demanded
a resolute-looking man in authority, who was

2512.text:
summoned out by the guard.
Naturally struck by the disagreeable word,

2519.text:
Charles Darnay requested the speaker to take
notice that he was a free traveller and French

2525.text:
citizen, in charge of an escort which the
disturbed state of the country had imposed

2530.text:
upon him, and which he had paid for.
"Where," repeated the same personage, without

2536.text:
taking any heed of him whatever, "are the
papers of this prisoner?"

2542.text:
The drunken patriot had them in his cap, and
produced them. Casting his eyes over Gabelle's

2548.text:
letter, the same personage in authority showed
some disorder and surprise, and looked at

2554.text:
Darnay with a close attention.
He left escort and escorted without saying

2560.text:
a word, however, and went into the guard-room;
meanwhile, they sat upon their horses outside

2566.text:
the gate. Looking about him while in this
state of suspense, Charles Darnay observed

2573.text:
that the gate was held by a mixed guard of
soldiers and patriots, the latter far outnumbering

2580.text:
the former; and that while ingress into the
city for peasants' carts bringing in supplies,

2585.text:
and for similar traffic and traffickers, was
easy enough, egress, even for the homeliest

2592.text:
people, was very difficult. A numerous medley
of men and women, not to mention beasts and

2600.text:
vehicles of various sorts, was waiting to
issue forth; but, the previous identification

2607.text:
was so strict, that they filtered through
the barrier very slowly. Some of these people

2613.text:
knew their turn for examination to be so far
off, that they lay down on the ground to sleep

2619.text:
or smoke, while others talked together, or
loitered about. The red cap and tri-colour

2626.text:
cockade were universal, both among men and
women.

2631.text:
When he had sat in his saddle some half-hour,
taking note of these things, Darnay found

2637.text:
himself confronted by the same man in authority,
who directed the guard to open the barrier.

2644.text:
Then he delivered to the escort, drunk and
sober, a receipt for the escorted, and requested

2650.text:
him to dismount. He did so, and the two patriots,
leading his tired horse, turned and rode away

2657.text:
without entering the city.
He accompanied his conductor into a guard-room,

2662.text:
smelling of common wine and tobacco, where
certain soldiers and patriots, asleep and

2669.text:
awake, drunk and sober, and in various neutral
states between sleeping and waking, drunkenness

2676.text:
and sobriety, were standing and lying about.
The light in the guard-house, half derived

2683.text:
from the waning oil-lamps of the night, and
half from the overcast day, was in a correspondingly

2690.text:
uncertain condition. Some registers were lying
open on a desk, and an officer of a coarse,

2697.text:
dark aspect, presided over these.
"Citizen Defarge," said he to Darnay's conductor,

2706.text:
as he took a slip of paper to write on. "Is
this the emigrant Evremonde?"

2722.text:
"In England."
"Without doubt. Where is your wife, Evremonde?"

2727.text:
"In England."
"Without doubt. You are consigned, Evremonde,

2732.text:
to the prison of La Force."
"Just Heaven!" exclaimed Darnay. "Under what

2738.text:
law, and for what offence?"
The officer looked up from his slip of paper

2743.text:
for a moment.
"We have new laws, Evremonde, and new offences,

2748.text:
since you were here." He said it with a hard
smile, and went on writing.

2754.text:
"I entreat you to observe that I have come
here voluntarily, in response to that written

2760.text:
appeal of a fellow-countryman which lies before
you. I demand no more than the opportunity

2766.text:
to do so without delay. Is not that my right?"
"Emigrants have no rights, Evremonde," was

2774.text:
the stolid reply. The officer wrote until
he had finished, read over to himself what

2780.text:
he had written, sanded it, and handed it to
Defarge, with the words "In secret."

2788.text:
Defarge motioned with the paper to the prisoner
that he must accompany him. The prisoner obeyed,

2793.text:
and a guard of two armed patriots attended
them.

2797.text:
"Is it you," said Defarge, in a low voice,
as they went down the guardhouse steps and

2803.text:
turned into Paris, "who married the daughter
of Doctor Manette, once a prisoner in the

2808.text:
Bastille that is no more?"
"Yes," replied Darnay, looking at him with

2815.text:
surprise.
"My name is Defarge, and I keep a wine-shop

2820.text:
in the Quarter Saint Antoine. Possibly you
have heard of me."

2824.text:
"My wife came to your house to reclaim her
father? Yes!"

2830.text:
The word "wife" seemed to serve as a gloomy
reminder to Defarge, to say with sudden impatience,

2837.text:
"In the name of that sharp female newly-born,
and called La Guillotine, why did you come

2845.text:
to France?"
"You heard me say why, a minute ago. Do you

2850.text:
not believe it is the truth?"
"A bad truth for you," said Defarge, speaking

2855.text:
with knitted brows, and looking straight before
him.

2859.text:
"Indeed I am lost here. All here is so unprecedented,
so changed, so sudden and unfair, that I am

2868.text:
absolutely lost. Will you render me a little
help?"

2871.text:
"None." Defarge spoke, always looking straight
before him.

2876.text:
"Will you answer me a single question?"
"Perhaps. According to its nature. You can

2883.text:
say what it is."
"In this prison that I am going to so unjustly,

2889.text:
shall I have some free communication with
the world outside?"

2892.text:
"You will see."
"I am not to be buried there, prejudged, and

2898.text:
without any means of presenting my case?"
"You will see. But, what then? Other people

2904.text:
have been similarly buried in worse prisons,
before now."

2908.text:
"But never by me, Citizen Defarge."
Defarge glanced darkly at him for answer,

2916.text:
and walked on in a steady and set silence.
The deeper he sank into this silence, the

2923.text:
fainter hope there was—or so Darnay thought—of
his softening in any slight degree. He, therefore,

2930.text:
made haste to say:
"It is of the utmost importance to me (you

2935.text:
know, Citizen, even better than I, of how
much importance), that I should be able to

2940.text:
communicate to Mr. Lorry of Tellson's Bank,
an English gentleman who is now in Paris,

2946.text:
the simple fact, without comment, that I have
been thrown into the prison of La Force. Will

2952.text:
you cause that to be done for me?"
"I will do," Defarge doggedly rejoined, "nothing

2960.text:
for you. My duty is to my country and the
People. I am the sworn servant of both, against

2967.text:
you. I will do nothing for you."
Charles Darnay felt it hopeless to entreat

2973.text:
him further, and his pride was touched besides.
As they walked on in silence, he could not

2980.text:
but see how used the people were to the spectacle
of prisoners passing along the streets. The

2986.text:
very children scarcely noticed him. A few
passers turned their heads, and a few shook

2992.text:
their fingers at him as an aristocrat; otherwise,
that a man in good clothes should be going

2998.text:
to prison, was no more remarkable than that
a labourer in working clothes should be going

3004.text:
to work. In one narrow, dark, and dirty street
through which they passed, an excited orator,

3011.text:
mounted on a stool, was addressing an excited
audience on the crimes against the people,

3018.text:
of the king and the royal family. The few
words that he caught from this man's lips,

3023.text:
first made it known to Charles Darnay that
the king was in prison, and that the foreign

3029.text:
ambassadors had one and all left Paris. On
the road (except at Beauvais) he had heard

3036.text:
absolutely nothing. The escort and the universal
watchfulness had completely isolated him.

3045.text:
That he had fallen among far greater dangers
than those which had developed themselves

3050.text:
when he left England, he of course knew now.
That perils had thickened about him fast,

3056.text:
and might thicken faster and faster yet, he
of course knew now. He could not but admit

3063.text:
to himself that he might not have made this
journey, if he could have foreseen the events

3068.text:
of a few days. And yet his misgivings were
not so dark as, imagined by the light of this

3074.text:
later time, they would appear. Troubled as
the future was, it was the unknown future,

3081.text:
and in its obscurity there was ignorant hope.
The horrible massacre, days and nights long,

3088.text:
which, within a few rounds of the clock, was
to set a great mark of blood upon the blessed

3094.text:
garnering time of harvest, was as far out
of his knowledge as if it had been a hundred

3099.text:
thousand years away. The "sharp female newly-born,
and called La Guillotine," was hardly known

3107.text:
to him, or to the generality of people, by
name. The frightful deeds that were to be

3113.text:
soon done, were probably unimagined at that
time in the brains of the doers. How could

3119.text:
they have a place in the shadowy conceptions
of a gentle mind?

3125.text:
Of unjust treatment in detention and hardship,
and in cruel separation from his wife and

3131.text:
child, he foreshadowed the likelihood, or
the certainty; but, beyond this, he dreaded

3138.text:
nothing distinctly. With this on his mind,
which was enough to carry into a dreary prison

3144.text:
courtyard, he arrived at the prison of La
Force.

3150.text:
A man with a bloated face opened the strong
wicket, to whom Defarge presented "The Emigrant

3156.text:
Evremonde."
"What the Devil! How many more of them!" exclaimed

3162.text:
the man with the bloated face.
Defarge took his receipt without noticing

3167.text:
the exclamation, and withdrew, with his two
fellow-patriots.

3171.text:
"What the Devil, I say again!" exclaimed the
gaoler, left with his wife. "How many more!"

3180.text:
The gaoler's wife, being provided with no
answer to the question, merely replied, "One

3186.text:
must have patience, my dear!" Three turnkeys
who entered responsive to a bell she rang,

3193.text:
echoed the sentiment, and one added, "For
the love of Liberty;" which sounded in that

3199.text:
place like an inappropriate conclusion.
The prison of La Force was a gloomy prison,

3207.text:
dark and filthy, and with a horrible smell
of foul sleep in it. Extraordinary how soon

3215.text:
the noisome flavour of imprisoned sleep, becomes
manifest in all such places that are ill cared

3223.text:
for!
"In secret, too," grumbled the gaoler, looking

3228.text:
at the written paper. "As if I was not already
full to bursting!"

3233.text:
He stuck the paper on a file, in an ill-humour,
and Charles Darnay awaited his further pleasure

3239.text:
for half an hour: sometimes, pacing to and
fro in the strong arched room: sometimes,

3247.text:
resting on a stone seat: in either case detained
to be imprinted on the memory of the chief

3253.text:
and his subordinates.
"Come!" said the chief, at length taking up

3258.text:
his keys, "come with me, emigrant."
Through the dismal prison twilight, his new

3265.text:
charge accompanied him by corridor and staircase,
many doors clanging and locking behind them,

3272.text:
until they came into a large, low, vaulted
chamber, crowded with prisoners of both sexes.

3279.text:
The women were seated at a long table, reading
and writing, knitting, sewing, and embroidering;

3286.text:
the men were for the most part standing behind
their chairs, or lingering up and down the

3291.text:
room.
In the instinctive association of prisoners

3295.text:
with shameful crime and disgrace, the new-comer
recoiled from this company. But the crowning

3302.text:
unreality of his long unreal ride, was, their
all at once rising to receive him, with every

3310.text:
refinement of manner known to the time, and
with all the engaging graces and courtesies

3315.text:
of life.
So strangely clouded were these refinements

3320.text:
by the prison manners and gloom, so spectral
did they become in the inappropriate squalor

3327.text:
and misery through which they were seen, that
Charles Darnay seemed to stand in a company

3333.text:
of the dead. Ghosts all! The ghost of beauty,
the ghost of stateliness, the ghost of elegance,

3342.text:
the ghost of pride, the ghost of frivolity,
the ghost of wit, the ghost of youth, the

3349.text:
ghost of age, all waiting their dismissal
from the desolate shore, all turning on him

3356.text:
eyes that were changed by the death they had
died in coming there.

3364.text:
It struck him motionless. The gaoler standing
at his side, and the other gaolers moving

3371.text:
about, who would have been well enough as
to appearance in the ordinary exercise of

3376.text:
their functions, looked so extravagantly coarse
contrasted with sorrowing mothers and blooming

3383.text:
daughters who were there—with the apparitions
of the coquette, the young beauty, and the

3389.text:
mature woman delicately bred—that the inversion
of all experience and likelihood which the

3395.text:
scene of shadows presented, was heightened
to its utmost. Surely, ghosts all. Surely,

3404.text:
the long unreal ride some progress of disease
that had brought him to these gloomy shades!

3411.text:
"In the name of the assembled companions in
misfortune," said a gentleman of courtly appearance

3419.text:
and address, coming forward, "I have the honour
of giving you welcome to La Force, and of

5098.text:
"My dear," said Mr. Lorry, striking in to
explain; "there are frequent risings in the

5105.text:
streets; and, although it is not likely they
will ever trouble you, Madame Defarge wishes

5110.text:
to see those whom she has the power to protect
at such times, to the end that she may know

5116.text:
them—that she may identify them. I believe,"
said Mr. Lorry, rather halting in his reassuring

5124.text:
words, as the stony manner of all the three
impressed itself upon him more and more, "I

5131.text:
state the case, Citizen Defarge?"
Defarge looked gloomily at his wife, and gave

5136.text:
no other answer than a gruff sound of acquiescence.
"You had better, Lucie," said Mr. Lorry, doing

5143.text:
all he could to propitiate, by tone and manner,
"have the dear child here, and our good Pross.

5149.text:
Our good Pross, Defarge, is an English lady,
and knows no French."

5155.text:
The lady in question, whose rooted conviction
that she was more than a match for any foreigner,

5161.text:
was not to be shaken by distress and, danger,
appeared with folded arms, and observed in

5167.text:
English to The Vengeance, whom her eyes first
encountered, "Well, I am sure, Boldface! I

5174.text:
hope _you_ are pretty well!" She also bestowed
a British cough on Madame Defarge; but, neither

5181.text:
of the two took much heed of her.
"Is that his child?" said Madame Defarge,

5188.text:
stopping in her work for the first time, and
pointing her knitting-needle at little Lucie

5193.text:
as if it were the finger of Fate.
"Yes, madame," answered Mr. Lorry; "this is

5199.text:
our poor prisoner's darling daughter, and
only child."

5203.text:
The shadow attendant on Madame Defarge and
her party seemed to fall so threatening and

5209.text:
dark on the child, that her mother instinctively
kneeled on the ground beside her, and held

5215.text:
her to her breast. The shadow attendant on
Madame Defarge and her party seemed then to

5222.text:
fall, threatening and dark, on both the mother
and the child.

5227.text:
"It is enough, my husband," said Madame Defarge.
"I have seen them. We may go."

5234.text:
But, the suppressed manner had enough of menace
in it—not visible and presented, but indistinct

5241.text:
and withheld—to alarm Lucie into saying,
as she laid her appealing hand on Madame Defarge's

5248.text:
dress:
"You will be good to my poor husband. You

5252.text:
will do him no harm. You will help me to see
him if you can?"

5256.text:
"Your husband is not my business here," returned
Madame Defarge, looking down at her with perfect

5263.text:
composure. "It is the daughter of your father
who is my business here."

5267.text:
"For my sake, then, be merciful to my husband.
For my child's sake! She will put her hands

5274.text:
together and pray you to be merciful. We are
more afraid of you than of these others."

5281.text:
Madame Defarge received it as a compliment,
and looked at her husband. Defarge, who had

5287.text:
been uneasily biting his thumb-nail and looking
at her, collected his face into a sterner

5293.text:
expression.
"What is it that your husband says in that

5297.text:
little letter?" asked Madame Defarge, with
a lowering smile. "Influence; he says something

5303.text:
touching influence?"
"That my father," said Lucie, hurriedly taking

5309.text:
the paper from her breast, but with her alarmed
eyes on her questioner and not on it, "has

5315.text:
much influence around him."
"Surely it will release him!" said Madame

5321.text:
Defarge. "Let it do so."
"As a wife and mother," cried Lucie, most

5326.text:
earnestly, "I implore you to have pity on
me and not to exercise any power that you

5332.text:
possess, against my innocent husband, but
to use it in his behalf. O sister-woman, think

5339.text:
of me. As a wife and mother!"
Madame Defarge looked, coldly as ever, at

5345.text:
the suppliant, and said, turning to her friend
The Vengeance:

5350.text:
"The wives and mothers we have been used to
see, since we were as little as this child,

5355.text:
and much less, have not been greatly considered?
We have known _their_ husbands and fathers

5361.text:
laid in prison and kept from them, often enough?
All our lives, we have seen our sister-women

5368.text:
suffer, in themselves and in their children,
poverty, nakedness, hunger, thirst, sickness,

5376.text:
misery, oppression and neglect of all kinds?"
"We have seen nothing else," returned The

5383.text:
Vengeance.
"We have borne this a long time," said Madame

5389.text:
Defarge, turning her eyes again upon Lucie.
"Judge you! Is it likely that the trouble

5394.text:
of one wife and mother would be much to us
now?"

5400.text:
She resumed her knitting and went out. The
Vengeance followed. Defarge went last, and

5407.text:
closed the door.
"Courage, my dear Lucie," said Mr. Lorry,

5412.text:
as he raised her. "Courage, courage! So far
all goes well with us—much, much better

5418.text:
than it has of late gone with many poor souls.
Cheer up, and have a thankful heart."

5423.text:
"I am not thankless, I hope, but that dreadful
woman seems to throw a shadow on me and on

5431.text:
all my hopes."
"Tut, tut!" said Mr. Lorry; "what is this

5435.text:
despondency in the brave little breast? A
shadow indeed! No substance in it, Lucie."

5442.text:
But the shadow of the manner of these Defarges
was dark upon himself, for all that, and in

5448.text:
his secret mind it troubled him greatly.
End of Book 3, Chapter 3

5457.text:
Chapter IV. Calm in Storm
Doctor Manette did not return until the morning

5464.text:
of the fourth day of his absence. So much
of what had happened in that dreadful time

5469.text:
as could be kept from the knowledge of Lucie
was so well concealed from her, that not until

5474.text:
long afterwards, when France and she were
far apart, did she know that eleven hundred

5480.text:
defenceless prisoners of both sexes and all
ages had been killed by the populace; that

5487.text:
four days and nights had been darkened by
this deed of horror; and that the air around

5492.text:
her had been tainted by the slain. She only
knew that there had been an attack upon the

5499.text:
prisons, that all political prisoners had
been in danger, and that some had been dragged

5504.text:
out by the crowd and murdered.
To Mr. Lorry, the Doctor communicated under

5509.text:
an injunction of secrecy on which he had no
need to dwell, that the crowd had taken him

5515.text:
through a scene of carnage to the prison of
La Force. That, in the prison he had found

5522.text:
a self-appointed Tribunal sitting, before
which the prisoners were brought singly, and

5527.text:
by which they were rapidly ordered to be put
forth to be massacred, or to be released,

5533.text:
or (in a few cases) to be sent back to their
cells. That, presented by his conductors to

5539.text:
this Tribunal, he had announced himself by
name and profession as having been for eighteen

5545.text:
years a secret and unaccused prisoner in the
Bastille; that, one of the body so sitting

5551.text:
in judgment had risen and identified him,
and that this man was Defarge.

5557.text:
That, hereupon he had ascertained, through
the registers on the table, that his son-in-law

5563.text:
was among the living prisoners, and had pleaded
hard to the Tribunal—of whom some members

5569.text:
were asleep and some awake, some dirty with
murder and some clean, some sober and some

5576.text:
not—for his life and liberty. That, in the
first frantic greetings lavished on himself

5582.text:
as a notable sufferer under the overthrown
system, it had been accorded to him to have

5588.text:
Charles Darnay brought before the lawless
Court, and examined. That, he seemed on the

5594.text:
point of being at once released, when the
tide in his favour met with some unexplained

5599.text:
check (not intelligible to the Doctor), which
led to a few words of secret conference. That,

5606.text:
the man sitting as President had then informed
Doctor Manette that the prisoner must remain

5612.text:
in custody, but should, for his sake, be held
inviolate in safe custody. That, immediately,

5620.text:
on a signal, the prisoner was removed to the
interior of the prison again; but, that he,

5626.text:
the Doctor, had then so strongly pleaded for
permission to remain and assure himself that

5632.text:
his son-in-law was, through no malice or mischance,
delivered to the concourse whose murderous

5638.text:
yells outside the gate had often drowned the
proceedings, that he had obtained the permission,

5643.text:
and had remained in that Hall of Blood until
the danger was over.

5649.text:
The sights he had seen there, with brief snatches
of food and sleep by intervals, shall remain

5655.text:
untold. The mad joy over the prisoners who
were saved, had astounded him scarcely less

5663.text:
than the mad ferocity against those who were
cut to pieces. One prisoner there was, he

5669.text:
said, who had been discharged into the street
free, but at whom a mistaken savage had thrust

5675.text:
a pike as he passed out. Being besought to
go to him and dress the wound, the Doctor

5681.text:
had passed out at the same gate, and had found
him in the arms of a company of Samaritans,

5687.text:
who were seated on the bodies of their victims.
With an inconsistency as monstrous as anything

5693.text:
in this awful nightmare, they had helped the
healer, and tended the wounded man with the

5699.text:
gentlest solicitude—had made a litter for
him and escorted him carefully from the spot—had

5705.text:
then caught up their weapons and plunged anew
into a butchery so dreadful, that the Doctor

5711.text:
had covered his eyes with his hands, and swooned
away in the midst of it.

5718.text:
As Mr. Lorry received these confidences, and
as he watched the face of his friend now sixty-two

5724.text:
years of age, a misgiving arose within him
that such dread experiences would revive the

5731.text:
old danger.
But, he had never seen his friend in his present

5735.text:
aspect: he had never at all known him in his
present character. For the first time the

5741.text:
Doctor felt, now, that his suffering was strength
and power. For the first time he felt that

5748.text:
in that sharp fire, he had slowly forged the
iron which could break the prison door of

5754.text:
his daughter's husband, and deliver him. "It
all tended to a good end, my friend; it was

5760.text:
not mere waste and ruin. As my beloved child
was helpful in restoring me to myself, I will

5768.text:
be helpful now in restoring the dearest part
of herself to her; by the aid of Heaven I

5774.text:
will do it!" Thus, Doctor Manette. And when
Jarvis Lorry saw the kindled eyes, the resolute

5783.text:
face, the calm strong look and bearing of
the man whose life always seemed to him to

5789.text:
have been stopped, like a clock, for so many
years, and then set going again with an energy

5795.text:
which had lain dormant during the cessation
of its usefulness, he believed.

5803.text:
Greater things than the Doctor had at that
time to contend with, would have yielded before

5807.text:
his persevering purpose. While he kept himself
in his place, as a physician, whose business

5813.text:
was with all degrees of mankind, bond and
free, rich and poor, bad and good, he used

5821.text:
his personal influence so wisely, that he
was soon the inspecting physician of three

5827.text:
prisons, and among them of La Force. He could
now assure Lucie that her husband was no longer

5833.text:
confined alone, but was mixed with the general
body of prisoners; he saw her husband weekly,

5840.text:
and brought sweet messages to her, straight
from his lips; sometimes her husband himself

5846.text:
sent a letter to her (though never by the
Doctor's hand), but she was not permitted

5850.text:
to write to him: for, among the many wild
suspicions of plots in the prisons, the wildest

5857.text:
of all pointed at emigrants who were known
to have made friends or permanent connections

5863.text:
abroad.
This new life of the Doctor's was an anxious

5868.text:
life, no doubt; still, the sagacious Mr. Lorry
saw that there was a new sustaining pride

5874.text:
in it. Nothing unbecoming tinged the pride;
it was a natural and worthy one; but he observed

5881.text:
it as a curiosity. The Doctor knew, that up
to that time, his imprisonment had been associated

5888.text:
in the minds of his daughter and his friend,
with his personal affliction, deprivation,

5893.text:
and weakness. Now that this was changed, and
he knew himself to be invested through that

5899.text:
old trial with forces to which they both looked
for Charles's ultimate safety and deliverance,

5905.text:
he became so far exalted by the change, that
he took the lead and direction, and required

5912.text:
them as the weak, to trust to him as the strong.
The preceding relative positions of himself

5920.text:
and Lucie were reversed, yet only as the liveliest
gratitude and affection could reverse them,

5927.text:
for he could have had no pride but in rendering
some service to her who had rendered so much

5933.text:
to him. "All curious to see," thought Mr.
Lorry, in his amiably shrewd way, "but all

5940.text:
natural and right; so, take the lead, my dear
friend, and keep it; it couldn't be in better

5945.text:
hands."
But, though the Doctor tried hard, and never

5950.text:
ceased trying, to get Charles Darnay set at
liberty, or at least to get him brought to

5957.text:
trial, the public current of the time set
too strong and fast for him. The new era began;

5963.text:
the king was tried, doomed, and beheaded;
the Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity,

5970.text:
or Death, declared for victory or death against
the world in arms; the black flag waved night

5978.text:
and day from the great towers of Notre Dame;
three hundred thousand men, summoned to rise

5984.text:
against the tyrants of the earth, rose from
all the varying soils of France, as if the

5990.text:
dragon's teeth had been sown broadcast, and
had yielded fruit equally on hill and plain,

5997.text:
on rock, in gravel, and alluvial mud, under
the bright sky of the South and under the

6003.text:
clouds of the North, in fell and forest, in
the vineyards and the olive-grounds and among

6009.text:
the cropped grass and the stubble of the corn,
along the fruitful banks of the broad rivers,

6015.text:
and in the sand of the sea-shore. What private
solicitude could rear itself against the deluge

6023.text:
of the Year One of Liberty—the deluge rising
from below, not falling from above, and with

6030.text:
the windows of Heaven shut, not opened!
There was no pause, no pity, no peace, no

6037.text:
interval of relenting rest, no measurement
of time. Though days and nights circled as

6044.text:
regularly as when time was young, and the
evening and morning were the first day, other

6050.text:
count of time there was none. Hold of it was
lost in the raging fever of a nation, as it

6056.text:
is in the fever of one patient. Now, breaking
the unnatural silence of a whole city, the

6063.text:
executioner showed the people the head of
the king—and now, it seemed almost in the

6069.text:
same breath, the head of his fair wife which
had had eight weary months of imprisoned widowhood

6075.text:
and misery, to turn it grey.
And yet, observing the strange law of contradiction

6083.text:
which obtains in all such cases, the time
was long, while it flamed by so fast. A revolutionary

6091.text:
tribunal in the capital, and forty or fifty
thousand revolutionary committees all over

6096.text:
the land; a law of the Suspected, which struck
away all security for liberty or life, and

6104.text:
delivered over any good and innocent person
to any bad and guilty one; prisons gorged

6110.text:
with people who had committed no offence,
and could obtain no hearing; these things

6115.text:
became the established order and nature of
appointed things, and seemed to be ancient

6121.text:
usage before they were many weeks old. Above
all, one hideous figure grew as familiar as

6128.text:
if it had been before the general gaze from
the foundations of the world—the figure

6134.text:
of the sharp female called La Guillotine.
It was the popular theme for jests; it was

6142.text:
the best cure for headache, it infallibly
prevented the hair from turning grey, it imparted

6148.text:
a peculiar delicacy to the complexion, it
was the National Razor which shaved close:

6155.text:
who kissed La Guillotine, looked through the
little window and sneezed into the sack. It

6160.text:
was the sign of the regeneration of the human
race. It superseded the Cross. Models of it

6166.text:
were worn on breasts from which the Cross
was discarded, and it was bowed down to and

6172.text:
believed in where the Cross was denied.
It sheared off heads so many, that it, and

6178.text:
the ground it most polluted, were a rotten
red. It was taken to pieces, like a toy-puzzle

6184.text:
for a young Devil, and was put together again
when the occasion wanted it. It hushed the

6190.text:
eloquent, struck down the powerful, abolished
the beautiful and good. Twenty-two friends

6196.text:
of high public mark, twenty-one living and
one dead, it had lopped the heads off, in

6202.text:
one morning, in as many minutes. The name
of the strong man of Old Scripture had descended

6208.text:
to the chief functionary who worked it; but,
so armed, he was stronger than his namesake,

6214.text:
and blinder, and tore away the gates of God's
own Temple every day.

6222.text:
Among these terrors, and the brood belonging
to them, the Doctor walked with a steady head:

6228.text:
confident in his power, cautiously persistent
in his end, never doubting that he would save

6233.text:
Lucie's husband at last. Yet the current of
the time swept by, so strong and deep, and

6241.text:
carried the time away so fiercely, that Charles
had lain in prison one year and three months

6247.text:
when the Doctor was thus steady and confident.
So much more wicked and distracted had the

6253.text:
Revolution grown in that December month, that
the rivers of the South were encumbered with

6259.text:
the bodies of the violently drowned by night,
and prisoners were shot in lines and squares

6265.text:
under the southern wintry sun. Still, the
Doctor walked among the terrors with a steady

6273.text:
head. No man better known than he, in Paris
at that day; no man in a stranger situation.

6281.text:
Silent, humane, indispensable in hospital
and prison, using his art equally among assassins

6289.text:
and victims, he was a man apart. In the exercise
of his skill, the appearance and the story

6295.text:
of the Bastille Captive removed him from all
other men. He was not suspected or brought

6302.text:
in question, any more than if he had indeed
been recalled to life some eighteen years

6308.text: before, or were a Spirit moving among mortals.

6320.text:
Chapter V. The Wood-Sawyer
One year and three months. During all that

6327.text:
time Lucie was never sure, from hour to hour,
but that the Guillotine would strike off her

6332.text:
husband's head next day. Every day, through
the stony streets, the tumbrils now jolted

6339.text:
heavily, filled with Condemned. Lovely girls;
bright women, brown-haired, black-haired,

6345.text:
and grey; youths; stalwart men and old; gentle
born and peasant born; all red wine for La

6354.text:
Guillotine, all daily brought into light from
the dark cellars of the loathsome prisons,

6360.text:
and carried to her through the streets to
slake her devouring thirst. Liberty, equality,

6367.text:
fraternity, or death;—the last, much the
easiest to bestow, O Guillotine!

6375.text:
If the suddenness of her calamity, and the
whirling wheels of the time, had stunned the

6381.text:
Doctor's daughter into awaiting the result
in idle despair, it would but have been with

6386.text:
her as it was with many. But, from the hour
when she had taken the white head to her fresh

6392.text:
young bosom in the garret of Saint Antoine,
she had been true to her duties. She was truest

6398.text:
to them in the season of trial, as all the
quietly loyal and good will always be.

6406.text:
As soon as they were established in their
new residence, and her father had entered

6411.text:
on the routine of his avocations, she arranged
the little household as exactly as if her

6417.text:
husband had been there. Everything had its
appointed place and its appointed time. Little

6422.text:
Lucie she taught, as regularly, as if they
had all been united in their English home.

6428.text:
The slight devices with which she cheated
herself into the show of a belief that they

6433.text:
would soon be reunited—the little preparations
for his speedy return, the setting aside of

6439.text:
his chair and his books—these, and the solemn
prayer at night for one dear prisoner especially,

6446.text:
among the many unhappy souls in prison and
the shadow of death—were almost the only

6452.text:
outspoken reliefs of her heavy mind.
She did not greatly alter in appearance. The

6459.text:
plain dark dresses, akin to mourning dresses,
which she and her child wore, were as neat

6466.text:
and as well attended to as the brighter clothes
of happy days. She lost her colour, and the

6472.text:
old and intent expression was a constant,
not an occasional, thing; otherwise, she remained

6479.text:
very pretty and comely. Sometimes, at night
on kissing her father, she would burst into

6485.text:
the grief she had repressed all day, and would
say that her sole reliance, under Heaven,

6491.text:
was on him. He always resolutely answered:
"Nothing can happen to him without my knowledge,

6498.text:
and I know that I can save him, Lucie."
They had not made the round of their changed

6504.text:
life many weeks, when her father said to her,
on coming home one evening:

6509.text:
"My dear, there is an upper window in the
prison, to which Charles can sometimes gain

6514.text:
access at three in the afternoon. When he
can get to it—which depends on many uncertainties

6520.text:
and incidents—he might see you in the street,
he thinks, if you stood in a certain place

6526.text:
that I can show you. But you will not be able
to see him, my poor child, and even if you

6531.text:
could, it would be unsafe for you to make
a sign of recognition."

6535.text:
"O show me the place, my father, and I will
go there every day."

6543.text:
From that time, in all weathers, she waited
there two hours. As the clock struck two,

6550.text:
she was there, and at four she turned resignedly
away. When it was not too wet or inclement

6557.text:
for her child to be with her, they went together;
at other times she was alone; but, she never

6562.text:
missed a single day.
It was the dark and dirty corner of a small

6567.text:
winding street. The hovel of a cutter of wood
into lengths for burning, was the only house

6574.text:
at that end; all else was wall. On the third
day of her being there, he noticed her.

6586.text:
This mode of address was now prescribed by
decree. It had been established voluntarily

6592.text:
some time ago, among the more thorough patriots;
but, was now law for everybody.

6598.text:
"Walking here again, citizeness?"
"You see me, citizen!"

6604.text:
The wood-sawyer, who was a little man with
a redundancy of gesture (he had once been

6609.text:
a mender of roads), cast a glance at the prison,
pointed at the prison, and putting his ten

6616.text:
fingers before his face to represent bars,
peeped through them jocosely.

6621.text:
"But it's not my business," said he. And went
on sawing his wood.

6626.text:
Next day he was looking out for her, and accosted
her the moment she appeared.

6636.text:
"Ah! A child too! Your mother, is it not,
my little citizeness?"

6643.text:
"Do I say yes, mamma?" whispered little Lucie,
drawing close to her.

6652.text:
"Ah! But it's not my business. My work is
my business. See my saw! I call it my Little

6659.text:
Guillotine. La, la, la; La, la, la! And off
his head comes!"

6664.text:
The billet fell as he spoke, and he threw
it into a basket.

6669.text:
"I call myself the Samson of the firewood
guillotine. See here again! Loo, loo, loo;

6676.text:
Loo, loo, loo! And off _her_ head comes! Now,
a child. Tickle, tickle; Pickle, pickle! And

6682.text:
off _its_ head comes. All the family!"
Lucie shuddered as he threw two more billets

6688.text:
into his basket, but it was impossible to
be there while the wood-sawyer was at work,

6693.text:
and not be in his sight. Thenceforth, to secure
his good will, she always spoke to him first,

6700.text:
and often gave him drink-money, which he readily
received.

6705.text:
He was an inquisitive fellow, and sometimes
when she had quite forgotten him in gazing

6710.text:
at the prison roof and grates, and in lifting
her heart up to her husband, she would come

6715.text:
to herself to find him looking at her, with
his knee on his bench and his saw stopped

6721.text:
in its work. "But it's not my business!" he
would generally say at those times, and would

6728.text:
briskly fall to his sawing again.
In all weathers, in the snow and frost of

6734.text:
winter, in the bitter winds of spring, in
the hot sunshine of summer, in the rains of

6739.text:
autumn, and again in the snow and frost of
winter, Lucie passed two hours of every day

6746.text:
at this place; and every day on leaving it,
she kissed the prison wall. Her husband saw

6753.text:
her (so she learned from her father) it might
be once in five or six times: it might be

6759.text:
twice or thrice running: it might be, not
for a week or a fortnight together. It was

6765.text:
enough that he could and did see her when
the chances served, and on that possibility

6771.text:
she would have waited out the day, seven days
a week.

6775.text:
These occupations brought her round to the
December month, wherein her father walked

6780.text:
among the terrors with a steady head. On a
lightly-snowing afternoon she arrived at the

6786.text:
usual corner. It was a day of some wild rejoicing,
and a festival. She had seen the houses, as

6792.text:
she came along, decorated with little pikes,
and with little red caps stuck upon them;

6799.text:
also, with tricoloured ribbons; also, with
the standard inscription (tricoloured letters

6804.text:
were the favourite), Republic One and Indivisible.
Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!

6814.text:
The miserable shop of the wood-sawyer was
so small, that its whole surface furnished

6820.text:
very indifferent space for this legend. He
had got somebody to scrawl it up for him,

6826.text:
however, who had squeezed Death in with most
inappropriate difficulty. On his house-top,

6833.text:
he displayed pike and cap, as a good citizen
must, and in a window he had stationed his

6839.text:
saw inscribed as his "Little Sainte Guillotine"—for
the great sharp female was by that time popularly

6847.text:
canonised. His shop was shut and he was not
there, which was a relief to Lucie, and left

6853.text:
her quite alone.
But, he was not far off, for presently she

6859.text:
heard a troubled movement and a shouting coming
along, which filled her with fear. A moment

6865.text:
afterwards, and a throng of people came pouring
round the corner by the prison wall, in the

6871.text:
midst of whom was the wood-sawyer hand in
hand with The Vengeance. There could not be

6876.text:
fewer than five hundred people, and they were
dancing like five thousand demons. There was

6883.text:
no other music than their own singing. They
danced to the popular Revolution song, keeping

6889.text:
a ferocious time that was like a gnashing
of teeth in unison. Men and women danced together,

6896.text:
women danced together, men danced together,
as hazard had brought them together. At first,

6902.text:
they were a mere storm of coarse red caps
and coarse woollen rags; but, as they filled

6909.text:
the place, and stopped to dance about Lucie,
some ghastly apparition of a dance-figure

6915.text:
gone raving mad arose among them. They advanced,
retreated, struck at one another's hands,

6922.text:
clutched at one another's heads, spun round
alone, caught one another and spun round in

6928.text:
pairs, until many of them dropped. While those
were down, the rest linked hand in hand, and

6935.text:
all spun round together: then the ring broke,
and in separate rings of two and four they

6941.text:
turned and turned until they all stopped at
once, began again, struck, clutched, and tore,

6948.text:
and then reversed the spin, and all spun round
another way. Suddenly they stopped again,

6955.text:
paused, struck out the time afresh, formed
into lines the width of the public way, and,

6961.text:
with their heads low down and their hands
high up, swooped screaming off. No fight could

6969.text:
have been half so terrible as this dance.
It was so emphatically a fallen sport—a

6976.text:
something, once innocent, delivered over to
all devilry—a healthy pastime changed into

6983.text:
a means of angering the blood, bewildering
the senses, and steeling the heart. Such grace

6991.text:
as was visible in it, made it the uglier,
showing how warped and perverted all things

6997.text:
good by nature were become. The maidenly bosom
bared to this, the pretty almost-child's head

7005.text:
thus distracted, the delicate foot mincing
in this slough of blood and dirt, were types

7011.text:
of the disjointed time.
This was the Carmagnole. As it passed, leaving

7018.text:
Lucie frightened and bewildered in the doorway
of the wood-sawyer's house, the feathery snow

7024.text:
fell as quietly and lay as white and soft,
as if it had never been.

7030.text:
"O my father!" for he stood before her when
she lifted up the eyes she had momentarily

7037.text:
darkened with her hand; "such a cruel, bad
sight."

7041.text:
"I know, my dear, I know. I have seen it many
times. Don't be frightened! Not one of them

7047.text:
would harm you."
"I am not frightened for myself, my father.

7052.text:
But when I think of my husband, and the mercies
of these people—"

7056.text:
"We will set him above their mercies very
soon. I left him climbing to the window, and

7062.text:
I came to tell you. There is no one here to
see. You may kiss your hand towards that highest

7068.text:
shelving roof."
"I do so, father, and I send him my Soul with

7073.text:
it!"
"You cannot see him, my poor dear?"

7076.text:
"No, father," said Lucie, yearning and weeping
as she kissed her hand, "no."

7084.text:
A footstep in the snow. Madame Defarge. "I
salute you, citizeness," from the Doctor.

7091.text:
"I salute you, citizen." This in passing.
Nothing more. Madame Defarge gone, like a

7097.text:
shadow over the white road.
"Give me your arm, my love. Pass from here

7103.text:
with an air of cheerfulness and courage, for
his sake. That was well done;" they had left

7108.text:
the spot; "it shall not be in vain. Charles
is summoned for to-morrow."

7113.text:
"For to-morrow!"
"There is no time to lose. I am well prepared,

7118.text:
but there are precautions to be taken, that
could not be taken until he was actually summoned

7124.text:
before the Tribunal. He has not received the
notice yet, but I know that he will presently

7129.text:
be summoned for to-morrow, and removed to
the Conciergerie; I have timely information.

7134.text:
You are not afraid?"
She could scarcely answer, "I trust in you."

7143.text:
"Do so, implicitly. Your suspense is nearly
ended, my darling; he shall be restored to

7148.text:
you within a few hours; I have encompassed
him with every protection. I must see Lorry."

7155.text:
He stopped. There was a heavy lumbering of
wheels within hearing. They both knew too

7160.text:
well what it meant. One. Two. Three. Three
tumbrils faring away with their dread loads

7169.text:
over the hushing snow.
"I must see Lorry," the Doctor repeated, turning

7174.text:
her another way.
The staunch old gentleman was still in his

7179.text:
trust; had never left it. He and his books
were in frequent requisition as to property

7184.text:
confiscated and made national. What he could
save for the owners, he saved. No better man

7191.text:
living to hold fast by what Tellson's had
in keeping, and to hold his peace.

7197.text:
A murky red and yellow sky, and a rising mist
from the Seine, denoted the approach of darkness.

7206.text:
It was almost dark when they arrived at the
Bank. The stately residence of Monseigneur

7211.text:
was altogether blighted and deserted. Above
a heap of dust and ashes in the court, ran

7218.text:
the letters: National Property. Republic One
and Indivisible. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity,

7226.text:
or Death!
Who could that be with Mr. Lorry—the owner

7230.text:
of the riding-coat upon the chair—who must
not be seen? From whom newly arrived, did

7236.text:
he come out, agitated and surprised, to take
his favourite in his arms? To whom did he

7242.text:
appear to repeat her faltering words, when,
raising his voice and turning his head towards

7248.text:
the door of the room from which he had issued,
he said: "Removed to the Conciergerie, and

7253.text:
summoned for to-morrow?"
End of Book 3, Chapter 5

7262.text:
Chapter VI. Triumph
The dread tribunal of five Judges, Public

7267.text:
Prosecutor, and determined Jury, sat every
day. Their lists went forth every evening,

7274.text:
and were read out by the gaolers of the various
prisons to their prisoners. The standard gaoler-joke

7280.text:
was, "Come out and listen to the Evening Paper,
you inside there!"

7284.text:
"Charles Evremonde, called Darnay!"
So at last began the Evening Paper at La Force.

7292.text:
When a name was called, its owner stepped
apart into a spot reserved for those who were

7298.text:
announced as being thus fatally recorded.
Charles Evremonde, called Darnay, had reason

7305.text:
to know the usage; he had seen hundreds pass
away so.

7309.text:
His bloated gaoler, who wore spectacles to
read with, glanced over them to assure himself

7316.text:
that he had taken his place, and went through
the list, making a similar short pause at

7321.text:
each name. There were twenty-three names,
but only twenty were responded to; for one

7327.text:
of the prisoners so summoned had died in gaol
and been forgotten, and two had already been

7332.text:
guillotined and forgotten. The list was read,
in the vaulted chamber where Darnay had seen

7338.text:
the associated prisoners on the night of his
arrival. Every one of those had perished in

7343.text:
the massacre; every human creature he had
since cared for and parted with, had died

7350.text:
on the scaffold.
There were hurried words of farewell and kindness,

7357.text:
but the parting was soon over. It was the
incident of every day, and the society of

7362.text:
La Force were engaged in the preparation of
some games of forfeits and a little concert,

7368.text:
for that evening. They crowded to the grates
and shed tears there; but, twenty places in

7375.text:
the projected entertainments had to be refilled,
and the time was, at best, short to the lock-up

7381.text:
hour, when the common rooms and corridors
would be delivered over to the great dogs

7386.text:
who kept watch there through the night. The
prisoners were far from insensible or unfeeling;

7393.text:
their ways arose out of the condition of the
time. Similarly, though with a subtle difference,

7400.text:
a species of fervour or intoxication, known,
without doubt, to have led some persons to

7407.text:
brave the guillotine unnecessarily, and to
die by it, was not mere boastfulness, but

7413.text:
a wild infection of the wildly shaken public
mind. In seasons of pestilence, some of us

7421.text:
will have a secret attraction to the disease—a
terrible passing inclination to die of it.

7429.text:
And all of us have like wonders hidden in
our breasts, only needing circumstances to

7436.text:
evoke them.
The passage to the Conciergerie was short

7441.text:
and dark; the night in its vermin-haunted
cells was long and cold. Next day, fifteen

7449.text:
prisoners were put to the bar before Charles
Darnay's name was called. All the fifteen

7454.text:
were condemned, and the trials of the whole
occupied an hour and a half.

7459.text:
"Charles Evremonde, called Darnay," was at
length arraigned.

7465.text:
His judges sat upon the Bench in feathered
hats; but the rough red cap and tricoloured

7472.text:
cockade was the head-dress otherwise prevailing.
Looking at the Jury and the turbulent audience,

7478.text:
he might have thought that the usual order
of things was reversed, and that the felons

7484.text:
were trying the honest men. The lowest, cruelest,
and worst populace of a city, never without

7491.text:
its quantity of low, cruel, and bad, were
the directing spirits of the scene: noisily

7497.text:
commenting, applauding, disapproving, anticipating,
and precipitating the result, without a check.

7506.text:
Of the men, the greater part were armed in
various ways; of the women, some wore knives,

7512.text:
some daggers, some ate and drank as they looked
on, many knitted. Among these last, was one,

7519.text:
with a spare piece of knitting under her arm
as she worked. She was in a front row, by

7525.text:
the side of a man whom he had never seen since
his arrival at the Barrier, but whom he directly

7530.text:
remembered as Defarge. He noticed that she
once or twice whispered in his ear, and that

7537.text:
she seemed to be his wife; but, what he most
noticed in the two figures was, that although

7544.text:
they were posted as close to himself as they
could be, they never looked towards him. They

7550.text:
seemed to be waiting for something with a
dogged determination, and they looked at the

7555.text:
Jury, but at nothing else. Under the President
sat Doctor Manette, in his usual quiet dress.

7563.text:
As well as the prisoner could see, he and
Mr. Lorry were the only men there, unconnected

7568.text:
with the Tribunal, who wore their usual clothes,
and had not assumed the coarse garb of the

7573.text:
Carmagnole.
Charles Evremonde, called Darnay, was accused

7579.text:
by the public prosecutor as an emigrant, whose
life was forfeit to the Republic, under the

7584.text:
decree which banished all emigrants on pain
of Death. It was nothing that the decree bore

7590.text:
date since his return to France. There he
was, and there was the decree; he had been

7595.text:
taken in France, and his head was demanded.
"Take off his head!" cried the audience. "An

7602.text:
enemy to the Republic!"
The President rang his bell to silence those

7607.text:
cries, and asked the prisoner whether it was
not true that he had lived many years in England?

7615.text:
Undoubtedly it was.
Was he not an emigrant then? What did he call

7619.text:
himself?
Not an emigrant, he hoped, within the sense

7623.text:
and spirit of the law.
Why not? the President desired to know.

7629.text:
Because he had voluntarily relinquished a
title that was distasteful to him, and a station

7634.text:
that was distasteful to him, and had left
his country—he submitted before the word

7640.text:
emigrant in the present acceptation by the
Tribunal was in use—to live by his own industry

7646.text:
in England, rather than on the industry of
the overladen people of France.

7652.text:
What proof had he of this?
He handed in the names of two witnesses; Theophile

7660.text:
Gabelle, and Alexandre Manette.
But he had married in England? the President

7664.text:
reminded him.
True, but not an English woman.

7667.text:
A citizeness of France?
Yes. By birth.

7671.text:
Her name and family?
"Lucie Manette, only daughter of Doctor Manette,

7677.text:
the good physician who sits there."
This answer had a happy effect upon the audience.

7685.text:
Cries in exaltation of the well-known good
physician rent the hall. So capriciously were

7691.text:
the people moved, that tears immediately rolled
down several ferocious countenances which

7698.text:
had been glaring at the prisoner a moment
before, as if with impatience to pluck him

7703.text:
out into the streets and kill him.
On these few steps of his dangerous way, Charles

7711.text:
Darnay had set his foot according to Doctor
Manette's reiterated instructions. The same

7717.text:
cautious counsel directed every step that
lay before him, and had prepared every inch

7723.text:
of his road.
The President asked, why had he returned to

7728.text:
France when he did, and not sooner?
He had not returned sooner, he replied, simply

7733.text:
because he had no means of living in France,
save those he had resigned; whereas, in England,

7740.text:
he lived by giving instruction in the French
language and literature. He had returned when

7745.text:
he did, on the pressing and written entreaty
of a French citizen, who represented that

7751.text:
his life was endangered by his absence. He
had come back, to save a citizen's life, and

7758.text:
to bear his testimony, at whatever personal
hazard, to the truth. Was that criminal in

7763.text:
the eyes of the Republic?
The populace cried enthusiastically, "No!"

7767.text:
and the President rang his bell to quiet them.
Which it did not, for they continued to cry

7776.text:
"No!" until they left off, of their own will.
The President required the name of that citizen.

7784.text:
The accused explained that the citizen was
his first witness. He also referred with confidence

7790.text:
to the citizen's letter, which had been taken
from him at the Barrier, but which he did

7795.text:
not doubt would be found among the papers
then before the President.

7799.text:
The Doctor had taken care that it should be
there—had assured him that it would be there—and

7804.text:
at this stage of the proceedings it was produced
and read. Citizen Gabelle was called to confirm

7811.text:
it, and did so. Citizen Gabelle hinted, with
infinite delicacy and politeness, that in

7817.text:
the pressure of business imposed on the Tribunal
by the multitude of enemies of the Republic

7823.text:
with which it had to deal, he had been slightly
overlooked in his prison of the Abbaye—in

7829.text:
fact, had rather passed out of the Tribunal's
patriotic remembrance—until three days ago;

7836.text:
when he had been summoned before it, and had
been set at liberty on the Jury's declaring

7841.text:
themselves satisfied that the accusation against
him was answered, as to himself, by the surrender

7848.text:
of the citizen Evremonde, called Darnay.
Doctor Manette was next questioned. His high

7855.text:
personal popularity, and the clearness of
his answers, made a great impression; but,

7861.text:
as he proceeded, as he showed that the Accused
was his first friend on his release from his

7866.text:
long imprisonment; that, the accused had remained
in England, always faithful and devoted to

7872.text:
his daughter and himself in their exile; that,
so far from being in favour with the Aristocrat

7878.text:
government there, he had actually been tried
for his life by it, as the foe of England

7884.text:
and friend of the United States—as he brought
these circumstances into view, with the greatest

7890.text:
discretion and with the straightforward force
of truth and earnestness, the Jury and the

7896.text:
populace became one. At last, when he appealed
by name to Monsieur Lorry, an English gentleman

7903.text:
then and there present, who, like himself,
had been a witness on that English trial and

7909.text:
could corroborate his account of it, the Jury
declared that they had heard enough, and that

7914.text:
they were ready with their votes if the President
were content to receive them.

7919.text:
At every vote (the Jurymen voted aloud and
individually), the populace set up a shout

7925.text:
of applause. All the voices were in the prisoner's
favour, and the President declared him free.

7932.text:
Then, began one of those extraordinary scenes
with which the populace sometimes gratified

7939.text:
their fickleness, or their better impulses
towards generosity and mercy, or which they

7945.text:
regarded as some set-off against their swollen
account of cruel rage. No man can decide now

7953.text:
to which of these motives such extraordinary
scenes were referable; it is probable, to

7959.text:
a blending of all the three, with the second
predominating. No sooner was the acquittal

7964.text:
pronounced, than tears were shed as freely
as blood at another time, and such fraternal

7971.text:
embraces were bestowed upon the prisoner by
as many of both sexes as could rush at him,

7977.text:
that after his long and unwholesome confinement
he was in danger of fainting from exhaustion;

7984.text:
none the less because he knew very well, that
the very same people, carried by another current,

7990.text:
would have rushed at him with the very same
intensity, to rend him to pieces and strew

7995.text:
him over the streets.
His removal, to make way for other accused

8000.text:
persons who were to be tried, rescued him
from these caresses for the moment. Five were

8006.text:
to be tried together, next, as enemies of
the Republic, forasmuch as they had not assisted

8012.text:
it by word or deed. So quick was the Tribunal
to compensate itself and the nation for a

8018.text:
chance lost, that these five came down to
him before he left the place, condemned to

8024.text:
die within twenty-four hours. The first of
them told him so, with the customary prison

8030.text:
sign of Death—a raised finger—and they
all added in words, "Long live the Republic!"

8039.text:
The five had had, it is true, no audience
to lengthen their proceedings, for when he

8044.text:
and Doctor Manette emerged from the gate,
there was a great crowd about it, in which

8049.text:
there seemed to be every face he had seen
in Court—except two, for which he looked

8055.text:
in vain. On his coming out, the concourse
made at him anew, weeping, embracing, and

8061.text:
shouting, all by turns and all together, until
the very tide of the river on the bank of

8068.text:
which the mad scene was acted, seemed to run
mad, like the people on the shore.

8074.text:
They put him into a great chair they had among
them, and which they had taken either out

8079.text:
of the Court itself, or one of its rooms or
passages. Over the chair they had thrown a

8084.text:
red flag, and to the back of it they had bound
a pike with a red cap on its top. In this

8091.text:
car of triumph, not even the Doctor's entreaties
could prevent his being carried to his home

8097.text:
on men's shoulders, with a confused sea of
red caps heaving about him, and casting up

8103.text:
to sight from the stormy deep such wrecks
of faces, that he more than once misdoubted

8109.text:
his mind being in confusion, and that he was
in the tumbril on his way to the Guillotine.

8116.text:
In wild dreamlike procession, embracing whom
they met and pointing him out, they carried

8123.text:
him on. Reddening the snowy streets with the
prevailing Republican colour, in winding and

8129.text:
tramping through them, as they had reddened
them below the snow with a deeper dye, they

8135.text:
carried him thus into the courtyard of the
building where he lived. Her father had gone

8141.text:
on before, to prepare her, and when her husband
stood upon his feet, she dropped insensible

8146.text:
in his arms.
As he held her to his heart and turned her

8152.text:
beautiful head between his face and the brawling
crowd, so that his tears and her lips might

8158.text:
come together unseen, a few of the people
fell to dancing. Instantly, all the rest fell

8165.text:
to dancing, and the courtyard overflowed with
the Carmagnole. Then, they elevated into the

8171.text:
vacant chair a young woman from the crowd
to be carried as the Goddess of Liberty, and

8177.text:
then swelling and overflowing out into the
adjacent streets, and along the river's bank,

8183.text:
and over the bridge, the Carmagnole absorbed
them every one and whirled them away.

8190.text:
After grasping the Doctor's hand, as he stood
victorious and proud before him; after grasping

8197.text:
the hand of Mr. Lorry, who came panting in
breathless from his struggle against the waterspout

8202.text:
of the Carmagnole; after kissing little Lucie,
who was lifted up to clasp her arms round

8208.text:
his neck; and after embracing the ever zealous
and faithful Pross who lifted her; he took

8214.text:
his wife in his arms, and carried her up to
their rooms.

8218.text:
"Lucie! My own! I am safe."
"O dearest Charles, let me thank God for this

8225.text:
on my knees as I have prayed to Him."
They all reverently bowed their heads and

8232.text:
hearts. When she was again in his arms, he
said to her:

8235.text:
"And now speak to your father, dearest. No
other man in all this France could have done

8241.text:
what he has done for me."
She laid her head upon her father's breast,

8247.text:
as she had laid his poor head on her own breast,
long, long ago. He was happy in the return

8255.text:
he had made her, he was recompensed for his
suffering, he was proud of his strength. "You

8261.text:
must not be weak, my darling," he remonstrated;
"don't tremble so. I have saved him."

8274.text:
Chapter VII. A Knock at the Door
"I have saved him." It was not another of

8281.text:
the dreams in which he had often come back;
he was really here. And yet his wife trembled,

8286.text:
and a vague but heavy fear was upon her.
All the air round was so thick and dark, the

8294.text:
people were so passionately revengeful and
fitful, the innocent were so constantly put

8300.text:
to death on vague suspicion and black malice,
it was so impossible to forget that many as

8307.text:
blameless as her husband and as dear to others
as he was to her, every day shared the fate

8313.text:
from which he had been clutched, that her
heart could not be as lightened of its load

8318.text:
as she felt it ought to be. The shadows of
the wintry afternoon were beginning to fall,

8324.text:
and even now the dreadful carts were rolling
through the streets. Her mind pursued them,

8331.text:
looking for him among the Condemned; and then
she clung closer to his real presence and

8336.text:
trembled more.
Her father, cheering her, showed a compassionate

8342.text:
superiority to this woman's weakness, which
was wonderful to see. No garret, no shoemaking,

8350.text:
no One Hundred and Five, North Tower, now!
He had accomplished the task he had set himself,

8356.text:
his promise was redeemed, he had saved Charles.
Let them all lean upon him.

8363.text:
Their housekeeping was of a very frugal kind:
not only because that was the safest way of

8369.text:
life, involving the least offence to the people,
but because they were not rich, and Charles,

8374.text:
throughout his imprisonment, had had to pay
heavily for his bad food, and for his guard,

8380.text:
and towards the living of the poorer prisoners.
Partly on this account, and partly to avoid

8386.text:
a domestic spy, they kept no servant; the
citizen and citizeness who acted as porters

8393.text:
at the courtyard gate, rendered them occasional
service; and Jerry (almost wholly transferred

8399.text:
to them by Mr. Lorry) had become their daily
retainer, and had his bed there every night.

8406.text:
