9935.text:
face that it was loss of time to dwell upon
the point. Confused, but sensible that something

9942.text:
might depend on his presence of mind, he commanded
himself, and was silently attentive.

9948.text:
"Now, I trust," said Sydney to him, "that
the name and influence of Doctor Manette may

9954.text:
stand him in as good stead to-morrow—you
said he would be before the Tribunal again

9959.text:
to-morrow, Mr. Barsad?—"
"Yes; I believe so."

9962.text:
"—In as good stead to-morrow as to-day.
But it may not be so. I own to you, I am shaken,

9969.text:
Mr. Lorry, by Doctor Manette's not having
had the power to prevent this arrest."

9974.text:
"He may not have known of it beforehand,"
said Mr. Lorry.

9978.text:
"But that very circumstance would be alarming,
when we remember how identified he is with

9984.text:
his son-in-law."
"That's true," Mr. Lorry acknowledged, with

9988.text:
his troubled hand at his chin, and his troubled
eyes on Carton.

9993.text:
"In short," said Sydney, "this is a desperate
time, when desperate games are played for

9999.text:
desperate stakes. Let the Doctor play the
winning game; I will play the losing one.

10005.text:
No man's life here is worth purchase. Any
one carried home by the people to-day, may

10011.text:
be condemned tomorrow. Now, the stake I have
resolved to play for, in case of the worst,

10018.text:
is a friend in the Conciergerie. And the friend
I purpose to myself to win, is Mr. Barsad."

10025.text:
"You need have good cards, sir," said the
spy.

10029.text:
"I'll run them over. I'll see what I hold,—Mr.
Lorry, you know what a brute I am; I wish

10035.text:
you'd give me a little brandy."
It was put before him, and he drank off a

10040.text:
glassful—drank off another glassful—pushed
the bottle thoughtfully away.

10045.text:
"Mr. Barsad," he went on, in the tone of one
who really was looking over a hand at cards:

10052.text:
"Sheep of the prisons, emissary of Republican
committees, now turnkey, now prisoner, always

10059.text:
spy and secret informer, so much the more
valuable here for being English that an Englishman

10065.text:
is less open to suspicion of subornation in
those characters than a Frenchman, represents

10070.text:
himself to his employers under a false name.
That's a very good card. Mr. Barsad, now in

10078.text:
the employ of the republican French government,
was formerly in the employ of the aristocratic

10083.text:
English government, the enemy of France and
freedom. That's an excellent card. Inference

10090.text:
clear as day in this region of suspicion,
that Mr. Barsad, still in the pay of the aristocratic

10096.text:
English government, is the spy of Pitt, the
treacherous foe of the Republic crouching

10102.text:
in its bosom, the English traitor and agent
of all mischief so much spoken of and so difficult

10109.text:
to find. That's a card not to be beaten. Have
you followed my hand, Mr. Barsad?"

10116.text:
"Not to understand your play," returned the
spy, somewhat uneasily.

10121.text:
"I play my Ace, Denunciation of Mr. Barsad
to the nearest Section Committee. Look over

10128.text:
your hand, Mr. Barsad, and see what you have.
Don't hurry."

10133.text:
He drew the bottle near, poured out another
glassful of brandy, and drank it off. He saw

10139.text:
that the spy was fearful of his drinking himself
into a fit state for the immediate denunciation

10145.text:
of him. Seeing it, he poured out and drank
another glassful.

10150.text:
"Look over your hand carefully, Mr. Barsad.
Take time."

10155.text:
It was a poorer hand than he suspected. Mr.
Barsad saw losing cards in it that Sydney

10161.text:
Carton knew nothing of. Thrown out of his
honourable employment in England, through

10166.text:
too much unsuccessful hard swearing there—not
because he was not wanted there; our English

10172.text:
reasons for vaunting our superiority to secrecy
and spies are of very modern date—he knew

10180.text:
that he had crossed the Channel, and accepted
service in France: first, as a tempter and

10186.text:
an eavesdropper among his own countrymen there:
gradually, as a tempter and an eavesdropper

10192.text:
among the natives. He knew that under the
overthrown government he had been a spy upon

10197.text:
Saint Antoine and Defarge's wine-shop; had
received from the watchful police such heads

10203.text:
of information concerning Doctor Manette's
imprisonment, release, and history, as should

10208.text:
serve him for an introduction to familiar
conversation with the Defarges; and tried

10213.text:
them on Madame Defarge, and had broken down
with them signally. He always remembered with

10219.text:
fear and trembling, that that terrible woman
had knitted when he talked with her, and had

10225.text:
looked ominously at him as her fingers moved.
He had since seen her, in the Section of Saint

10231.text:
Antoine, over and over again produce her knitted
registers, and denounce people whose lives

10238.text:
the guillotine then surely swallowed up. He
knew, as every one employed as he was did,

10245.text:
that he was never safe; that flight was impossible;
that he was tied fast under the shadow of

10251.text:
the axe; and that in spite of his utmost tergiversation
and treachery in furtherance of the reigning

10258.text:
terror, a word might bring it down upon him.
Once denounced, and on such grave grounds

10265.text:
as had just now been suggested to his mind,
he foresaw that the dreadful woman of whose

10271.text:
unrelenting character he had seen many proofs,
would produce against him that fatal register,

10279.text:
and would quash his last chance of life. Besides
that all secret men are men soon terrified,

10286.text:
here were surely cards enough of one black
suit, to justify the holder in growing rather

10293.text:
livid as he turned them over.
"You scarcely seem to like your hand," said

10300.text:
Sydney, with the greatest composure. "Do you
play?"

10303.text:
"I think, sir," said the spy, in the meanest
manner, as he turned to Mr. Lorry, "I may

10310.text:
appeal to a gentleman of your years and benevolence,
to put it to this other gentleman, so much

10315.text:
your junior, whether he can under any circumstances
reconcile it to his station to play that Ace

10322.text:
of which he has spoken. I admit that _I_ am
a spy, and that it is considered a discreditable

10328.text:
station—though it must be filled by somebody;
but this gentleman is no spy, and why should

10334.text:
he so demean himself as to make himself one?"
"I play my Ace, Mr. Barsad," said Carton,

10341.text:
taking the answer on himself, and looking
at his watch, "without any scruple, in a very

10346.text:
few minutes."
"I should have hoped, gentlemen both," said

10351.text:
the spy, always striving to hook Mr. Lorry
into the discussion, "that your respect for

10357.text:
my sister—"
"I could not better testify my respect for

10361.text:
your sister than by finally relieving her
of her brother," said Sydney Carton.

10366.text:
"You think not, sir?"
"I have thoroughly made up my mind about it."

10373.text:
The smooth manner of the spy, curiously in
dissonance with his ostentatiously rough dress,

10380.text:
and probably with his usual demeanour, received
such a check from the inscrutability of Carton,—who

10387.text:
was a mystery to wiser and honester men than
he,—that it faltered here and failed him.

10394.text:
While he was at a loss, Carton said, resuming
his former air of contemplating cards:

10399.text:
"And indeed, now I think again, I have a strong
impression that I have another good card here,

10406.text:
not yet enumerated. That friend and fellow-Sheep,
who spoke of himself as pasturing in the country

10412.text:
prisons; who was he?"
"French. You don't know him," said the spy,

10417.text:
quickly.
"French, eh?" repeated Carton, musing, and

10420.text:
not appearing to notice him at all, though
he echoed his word. "Well; he may be."

10426.text:
"Is, I assure you," said the spy; "though
it's not important."

10429.text:
"Though it's not important," repeated Carton,
in the same mechanical way—"though it's

10435.text:
not important—No, it's not important. No.
Yet I know the face."

10439.text:
"I think not. I am sure not. It can't be,"
said the spy.

10443.text:
"It-can't-be," muttered Sydney Carton, retrospectively,
and idling his glass (which fortunately was

10450.text:
a small one) again. "Can't-be. Spoke good
French. Yet like a foreigner, I thought?"

10456.text:
"Provincial," said the spy.
"No. Foreign!" cried Carton, striking his

10462.text:
open hand on the table, as a light broke clearly
on his mind. "Cly! Disguised, but the same

10469.text:
man. We had that man before us at the Old
Bailey."

10473.text:
"Now, there you are hasty, sir," said Barsad,
with a smile that gave his aquiline nose an

10480.text:
extra inclination to one side; "there you
really give me an advantage over you. Cly

10486.text:
(who I will unreservedly admit, at this distance
of time, was a partner of mine) has been dead

10492.text:
several years. I attended him in his last
illness. He was buried in London, at the church

10498.text:
of Saint Pancras-in-the-Fields. His unpopularity
with the blackguard multitude at the moment

10504.text:
prevented my following his remains, but I
helped to lay him in his coffin."

10508.text:
Here, Mr. Lorry became aware, from where he
sat, of a most remarkable goblin shadow on

10515.text:
the wall. Tracing it to its source, he discovered
it to be caused by a sudden extraordinary

10522.text:
rising and stiffening of all the risen and
stiff hair on Mr. Cruncher's head.

10527.text:
"Let us be reasonable," said the spy, "and
let us be fair. To show you how mistaken you

10533.text:
are, and what an unfounded assumption yours
is, I will lay before you a certificate of

10539.text:
Cly's burial, which I happened to have carried
in my pocket-book," with a hurried hand he

10544.text:
produced and opened it, "ever since. There
it is. Oh, look at it, look at it! You may

10549.text:
take it in your hand; it's no forgery."
Here, Mr. Lorry perceived the reflection on

10555.text:
the wall to elongate, and Mr. Cruncher rose
and stepped forward. His hair could not have

10561.text:
been more violently on end, if it had been
that moment dressed by the Cow with the crumpled

10568.text:
horn in the house that Jack built.
Unseen by the spy, Mr. Cruncher stood at his

10574.text:
side, and touched him on the shoulder like
a ghostly bailiff.

10578.text:
"That there Roger Cly, master," said Mr. Cruncher,
with a taciturn and iron-bound visage. "So

10586.text:
_you_ put him in his coffin?"
"I did."

10591.text:
"Who took him out of it?"
Barsad leaned back in his chair, and stammered,

10597.text:
"What do you mean?"
"I mean," said Mr. Cruncher, "that he warn't

10602.text:
never in it. No! Not he! I'll have my head
took off, if he was ever in it."

10607.text:
The spy looked round at the two gentlemen;
they both looked in unspeakable astonishment

10612.text:
at Jerry.
"I tell you," said Jerry, "that you buried

10617.text:
paving-stones and earth in that there coffin.
Don't go and tell me that you buried Cly.

10624.text:
It was a take in. Me and two more knows it."
"How do you know it?"

10629.text:
"What's that to you? Ecod!" growled Mr. Cruncher,
"it's you I have got a old grudge again, is

10636.text:
it, with your shameful impositions upon tradesmen!
I'd catch hold of your throat and choke you

10642.text:
for half a guinea."
Sydney Carton, who, with Mr. Lorry, had been

10646.text:
lost in amazement at this turn of the business,
here requested Mr. Cruncher to moderate and

10652.text:
explain himself.
"At another time, sir," he returned, evasively,

10658.text:
"the present time is ill-conwenient for explainin'.
What I stand to, is, that he knows well wot

10665.text:
that there Cly was never in that there coffin.
Let him say he was, in so much as a word of

10671.text:
one syllable, and I'll either catch hold of
his throat and choke him for half a guinea;"

10676.text:
Mr. Cruncher dwelt upon this as quite a liberal
offer; "or I'll out and announce him."

10682.text:
"Humph! I see one thing," said Carton. "I
hold another card, Mr. Barsad. Impossible,

10690.text:
here in raging Paris, with Suspicion filling
the air, for you to outlive denunciation,

10696.text:
when you are in communication with another
aristocratic spy of the same antecedents as

10702.text:
yourself, who, moreover, has the mystery about
him of having feigned death and come to life

10709.text:
again! A plot in the prisons, of the foreigner
against the Republic. A strong card—a certain

10715.text:
Guillotine card! Do you play?"
"No!" returned the spy. "I throw up. I confess

10722.text:
that we were so unpopular with the outrageous
mob, that I only got away from England at

10727.text:
the risk of being ducked to death, and that
Cly was so ferreted up and down, that he never

10732.text:
would have got away at all but for that sham.
Though how this man knows it was a sham, is

10738.text:
a wonder of wonders to me."
"Never you trouble your head about this man,"

10743.text:
retorted the contentious Mr. Cruncher; "you'll
have trouble enough with giving your attention

10749.text:
to that gentleman. And look here! Once more!"—Mr.
Cruncher could not be restrained from making

10754.text:
rather an ostentatious parade of his liberality—"I'd
catch hold of your throat and choke you for

10761.text:
half a guinea."
The Sheep of the prisons turned from him to

10765.text:
Sydney Carton, and said, with more decision,
"It has come to a point. I go on duty soon,

10771.text:
and can't overstay my time. You told me you
had a proposal; what is it? Now, it is of

10777.text:
no use asking too much of me. Ask me to do
anything in my office, putting my head in

10781.text:
great extra danger, and I had better trust
my life to the chances of a refusal than the

10787.text:
chances of consent. In short, I should make
that choice. You talk of desperation. We are

10793.text:
all desperate here. Remember! I may denounce
you if I think proper, and I can swear my

10799.text:
way through stone walls, and so can others.
Now, what do you want with me?"

10805.text:
"Not very much. You are a turnkey at the Conciergerie?"
"I tell you once for all, there is no such

10812.text:
thing as an escape possible," said the spy,
firmly.

10815.text:
"Why need you tell me what I have not asked?
You are a turnkey at the Conciergerie?"

10821.text:
"I am sometimes."
"You can be when you choose?"

10825.text:
"I can pass in and out when I choose."
Sydney Carton filled another glass with brandy,

10832.text:
poured it slowly out upon the hearth, and
watched it as it dropped. It being all spent,

10838.text:
he said, rising:
"So far, we have spoken before these two,

10843.text:
because it was as well that the merits of
the cards should not rest solely between you

10848.text:
and me. Come into the dark room here, and
let us have one final word alone."
